animals.name: Bengal Tiger
animals.description: The Bengal tiger is a majestic big cat known for its striking orange coat with black stripes. Each tiger's stripe pattern is unique, much like human fingerprints. They are solitary hunters and primarily nocturnal.
facts: Largest tiger species in the world
Can swim up to 6 kilometers
Stripes help them camouflage in tall grass
A single tiger can eat up to 40 kg of meat in one night
animals.conservationInfo: Habitat loss and poaching have severely reduced their population. Conservation efforts include protected reserves and anti-poaching measures.
animals.dietInfo: Primarily hunts deer, wild boar, and other large mammals. They are apex predators in their ecosystem.
animals.behavior: Solitary animals that mark their territory with urine and scratch marks. They are most active during dawn and dusk.

animals.name: Mountain Gorilla
animals.description: Mountain gorillas are the largest living primates and share 98% of their DNA with humans. They live in family groups led by a dominant silverback male.
facts: Use tools like sticks to measure water depth
Build new nests every day from vegetation
Communicate using 25 different sounds
Infants ride on their mothers' backs for 3-4 years
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by habitat loss, poaching, and human diseases. Only about 1,000 remain in the wild.
animals.dietInfo: Primarily eats leaves, shoots, stems, and occasionally fruit. They spend about 30% of their day feeding.
animals.behavior: Live in stable family groups. Silverbacks protect the group and make all major decisions.

animals.name: African Elephant
animals.description: The African elephant is the largest land animal on Earth. They have complex social structures and are known for their intelligence and memory.
facts: Trunk has over 40,000 muscles
Can communicate using infrasound below human hearing
Recognize themselves in mirrors
Mourn their dead and visit burial sites
animals.conservationInfo: Severely threatened by ivory poaching and habitat fragmentation. Conservation includes anti-poaching patrols and habitat corridors.
animals.dietInfo: Eats up to 300 pounds of vegetation daily including grass, leaves, bark, and fruit.
animals.behavior: Live in matriarchal herds. Use tools and show empathy toward other elephants.

animals.name: Giant Panda
animals.description: Giant pandas are beloved bears known for their distinctive black and white coloring. Despite being classified as carnivores, they survive almost entirely on bamboo.
facts: Spend 10-16 hours a day eating bamboo
Have an extended wrist bone that functions like a thumb
Newborns are 1/900th the size of their mother
Can stand on their hind legs to appear larger
animals.conservationInfo: Conservation efforts in China have helped increase their population through protected reserves and breeding programs.
animals.dietInfo: 99% of their diet is bamboo. They have special digestive systems to process this tough plant.
animals.behavior: Mostly solitary except during mating season. Excellent climbers despite their size.

animals.name: African Lion
animals.description: Known as the 'king of the jungle,' lions are the only cats that live in social groups called prides. Males are recognizable by their magnificent manes.
facts: A lion's roar can be heard up to 8 km away
Females do 85-90% of the hunting
Sleep for 16-20 hours per day
Manes darken with age and indicate fitness
animals.conservationInfo: Population has declined by 43% in the last 21 years due to habitat loss and human conflict.
animals.dietInfo: Hunt large herbivores like wildebeest, zebra, and buffalo. They are opportunistic feeders.
animals.behavior: Live in prides of related females and their offspring. Males defend the territory.

animals.name: Emperor Penguin
animals.description: The largest of all penguins, emperor penguins are famous for their incredible breeding cycle in the harsh Antarctic winter.
facts: Can dive deeper than any other bird - up to 565 meters
Males incubate eggs for 2 months without eating
Huddle together for warmth in -60°C temperatures
Have specially adapted hemoglobin for deep diving
animals.conservationInfo: Climate change threatens their sea ice breeding grounds. Protected under Antarctic Treaty.
animals.dietInfo: Primarily eat fish, squid, and krill. Can hold their breath for up to 20 minutes while hunting.
animals.behavior: Form large colonies for breeding. Males balance eggs on their feet to keep them warm.

animals.name: Toco Toucan
animals.description: The largest and most recognizable toucan species, known for its enormous colorful bill that comprises one-third of its body length.
facts: Bill is lightweight despite its size
Uses bill to regulate body temperature
Nests in tree cavities
Can throw fruit up and catch it in its bill
animals.conservationInfo: Widespread and common, though habitat loss affects local populations.
animals.dietInfo: Eats mostly fruit but also insects, eggs, and small reptiles. Important seed dispersers.
animals.behavior: Social birds that live in small flocks. Communicate with croaking calls.

animals.name: Howler Monkey
animals.description: Known for their incredibly loud calls that can travel 5 km through dense forest. They are the largest New World monkeys.
facts: Loudest land animal in the Western Hemisphere
Prehensile tail acts as a fifth limb
Spend 70% of their time resting
Live in troops of 6-15 individuals
animals.conservationInfo: Some species are threatened by habitat loss, but most populations are stable.
animals.dietInfo: Primarily eat leaves, supplemented with fruits and flowers. Have specialized digestive systems.
animals.behavior: Arboreal and diurnal. Use loud calls to mark territory and communicate with other troops.

animals.name: Nile Crocodile
animals.description: Africa's largest freshwater predator, known for its immense power and ancient lineage dating back to the time of dinosaurs.
facts: Can hold breath for up to 2 hours underwater
Has the strongest bite of any animal
Temperature determines offspring gender
Can live up to 70-100 years
animals.conservationInfo: Population recovered after past overhunting. Now protected in many areas.
animals.dietInfo: Apex predator that eats fish, birds, and mammals. Uses 'death roll' to subdue large prey.
animals.behavior: Ambush predators that bask in the sun to regulate body temperature. Excellent swimmers.

animals.name: Snow Leopard
animals.description: Known as the 'ghost of the mountains,' snow leopards are perfectly adapted to life in high altitudes with thick fur and large paws.
facts: Can jump up to 15 meters horizontally
Use their tail as a blanket in cold weather
Paws act as natural snowshoes
Rarely seen by humans due to elusive nature
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by poaching and habitat loss. Only 4,000-6,500 remain in the wild.
animals.dietInfo: Hunt blue sheep, ibex, and smaller mammals. Can take down prey three times their weight.
animals.behavior: Solitary and crepuscular. Mark territory with scrapes and scent marks.

animals.name: Orangutan
animals.description: The 'person of the forest' is one of our closest relatives, sharing 97% of our DNA. They are the largest arboreal mammals.
facts: Build new nests every night in trees
Use leaves as umbrellas and tools
Males develop large cheek pads when mature
Can live up to 50 years in the wild
animals.conservationInfo: Critically endangered due to deforestation for palm oil plantations.
animals.dietInfo: Eat over 400 types of food including fruits, leaves, bark, and occasionally insects.
animals.behavior: Mostly solitary. Females raise offspring for 6-8 years, the longest childhood of any animal except humans.

animals.name: Arctic Fox
animals.description: Perfectly adapted to frigid environments, arctic foxes change their coat color with the seasons and can survive temperatures as low as -50°C.
facts: Fur changes from white to brown with seasons
Can survive temperatures of -50°C
Follow polar bears to scavenge leftovers
Have the warmest fur of any mammal
animals.conservationInfo: Population fluctuates with prey availability. Climate change poses long-term threats.
animals.dietInfo: Eats lemmings, voles, birds, eggs, and carrion. Caches extra food for winter.
animals.behavior: Monogamous and live in family groups. Use complex tunnel systems for shelter.

animals.name: Red Panda
animals.description: Despite its name, the red panda is not closely related to the giant panda. It's a unique species with cat-like features and a bushy tail.
facts: Has a false thumb for gripping bamboo
Can rotate ankles to climb down trees headfirst
Uses tail as blanket in cold weather
Communicates with twittering sounds
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by habitat loss and poaching. Protected in many national parks.
animals.dietInfo: Primarily eats bamboo, but also consumes eggs, birds, and insects.
animals.behavior: Mostly solitary and crepuscular. Excellent climbers that rarely come to the ground.

animals.name: Komodo Dragon
animals.description: The world's largest living lizard, known for its impressive size, powerful bite, and venomous saliva.
facts: Can run up to 20 km/h in short bursts
Has venom that prevents blood clotting
Can eat up to 80% of body weight in one meal
Has a keen sense of smell
animals.conservationInfo: Protected in Komodo National Park. Threatened by habitat loss and prey depletion.
animals.dietInfo: Eats deer, pigs, water buffalo, and occasionally smaller dragons.
animals.behavior: Solitary hunters that use ambush tactics. Excellent swimmers between islands.

animals.name: Polar Bear
animals.description: The largest land carnivore, perfectly adapted to life in the Arctic with thick fur, fat layers, and large paws.
facts: Black skin under white fur for heat absorption
Can smell prey from over 1 km away
Excellent swimmers with webbed front paws
Nearly transparent fur appears white
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by climate change reducing sea ice habitat.
animals.dietInfo: Primarily eats seals, especially ringed and bearded seals.
animals.behavior: Solitary except during mating season. Excellent swimmers and hunters.

animals.name: Blue Whale
animals.description: The largest animal ever known to have existed, even larger than the largest dinosaurs.
facts: Heart is the size of a small car
Can be heard hundreds of kilometers away
Newborn gains 90 kg per day
Tongue weighs as much as an elephant
animals.conservationInfo: Protected from commercial whaling since 1966, but populations slowly recovering.
animals.dietInfo: Eats up to 4 tons of krill per day during feeding season.
animals.behavior: Usually solitary or in small groups. Migrate long distances between feeding and breeding grounds.

animals.name: Humpback Whale
animals.description: Known for their spectacular breaching behavior and complex songs that can travel great distances underwater.
facts: Songs can last up to 20 minutes
Has the longest migration of any mammal
Uses bubble nets to catch fish
Flippers are one-third of body length
animals.conservationInfo: Population recovering after whaling bans, but still threatened by ship strikes.
animals.dietInfo: Eats krill, plankton, and small fish like herring and mackerel.
animals.behavior: Social animals that use cooperative hunting techniques. Known for acrobatic breaches.

animals.name: Great White Shark
animals.description: One of the most powerful predators in the ocean, known for its size, speed, and impressive hunting abilities.
facts: Can detect one drop of blood in 100 liters of water
Has up to 300 serrated teeth
Can jump 3 meters out of water
Body temperature warmer than surrounding water
animals.conservationInfo: Protected in many areas, but threatened by bycatch and shark finning.
animals.dietInfo: Eats seals, sea lions, fish, and occasionally dolphins and whales.
animals.behavior: Solitary hunters that use surprise attacks from below. Migrate long distances.

animals.name: Bald Eagle
animals.description: The national bird of the United States, known for its striking white head and tail contrasting with dark brown body.
facts: Can see fish from hundreds of feet away
Nests can weigh over 1 ton
Can fly up to 160 km/h
Mate for life with elaborate courtship rituals
animals.conservationInfo: Successfully recovered from endangered status through conservation efforts.
animals.dietInfo: Primarily eats fish, but also takes waterfowl and small mammals.
animals.behavior: Build massive nests in tall trees. Excellent fishers and scavengers.

animals.name: Gray Wolf
animals.description: The largest wild member of the dog family, living and hunting in packs with complex social structures.
facts: Can travel up to 200 km in a single day
Howl to communicate over long distances
Live in packs of 2-42 individuals
Can run at 60 km/h when chasing prey
animals.conservationInfo: Recovering in many areas after near extinction, but still persecuted in some regions.
animals.dietInfo: Hunts large ungulates like deer, elk, and moose in coordinated pack attacks.
animals.behavior: Highly social with complex pack hierarchy. Use cooperative hunting strategies.

animals.name: Giraffe
animals.description: The tallest land animal, known for its extremely long neck and legs, and distinctive spotted pattern.
facts: Newborns are 1.8 meters tall at birth
Heart weighs up to 11 kg to pump blood to brain
Only need 5-30 minutes of sleep per day
Tongue is 45-50 cm long
animals.conservationInfo: Population declining due to habitat loss and poaching.
animals.dietInfo: Eats leaves, fruits, and flowers from tall trees, especially acacia.
animals.behavior: Live in loose herds. Use necks as weapons in combat between males.

animals.name: Hippopotamus
animals.description: Despite their bulky appearance, hippos are surprisingly agile in water and are considered one of Africa's most dangerous animals.
facts: Can hold breath for up to 5 minutes
Sweat acts as natural sunscreen
Can run up to 30 km/h on land
Most human fatalities in Africa
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by habitat loss and illegal hunting for meat and ivory.
animals.dietInfo: Graze on grass at night, consuming up to 35 kg per night.
animals.behavior: Semi-aquatic, spending days in water and nights grazing on land. Highly territorial.

animals.name: Kangaroo
animals.description: Iconic Australian marsupials known for their powerful hind legs, large feet, and hopping locomotion.
facts: Can hop at 70 km/h
Use tail as fifth limb when walking slowly
Female can pause pregnancy during drought
Can jump 3 meters high and 9 meters long
animals.conservationInfo: Common and widespread, but some species threatened by habitat loss.
animals.dietInfo: Graze on grasses and herbs, requiring very little water.
animals.behavior: Live in mobs. Use boxing and kicking for dominance and defense.

animals.name: Koala
animals.description: Tree-dwelling marsupials known for their teddy bear appearance and eucalyptus leaf diet.
facts: Sleep 18-22 hours per day
Fingerprints similar to humans
Get most water from eucalyptus leaves
Babies eat mother's poop to get digestive bacteria
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by habitat destruction, climate change, and disease.
animals.dietInfo: Eats only certain types of eucalyptus leaves, which are toxic to most animals.
animals.behavior: Solitary and sedentary. Spend most time sleeping and eating in trees.

animals.name: Platypus
animals.description: One of only five monotreme species (egg-laying mammals), with a unique combination of features from different animals.
facts: One of few venomous mammals
Uses electroreception to find prey
Lays eggs but produces milk
Bill resembles a duck's but is soft and flexible
animals.conservationInfo: Protected but threatened by water pollution and habitat modification.
animals.dietInfo: Eats aquatic insects, larvae, shrimp, and crayfish.
animals.behavior: Mostly nocturnal. Excellent swimmers that close eyes and ears underwater.

animals.name: Cheetah
animals.description: The world's fastest land animal, built for speed with a lightweight body, long legs, and specialized respiratory system.
facts: Can accelerate from 0-100 km/h in 3 seconds
Only big cat that can't roar
Uses tail as rudder when running
Needs to rest after short bursts of speed
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by habitat loss and conflict with humans.
animals.dietInfo: Hunts small to medium-sized antelope during daylight hours.
animals.behavior: Diurnal hunters that use exceptional speed rather than strength.

animals.name: Leopard
animals.description: The most widespread big cat, known for its strength, stealth, and ability to adapt to various habitats.
facts: Can carry prey twice its weight up trees
Rosette patterns are unique like fingerprints
Excellent swimmers and climbers
Most secretive of big cats
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by habitat loss and poaching for skins and body parts.
animals.dietInfo: Opportunistic hunter eating over 90 species from insects to large antelope.
animals.behavior: Solitary and nocturnal. Drags prey into trees to protect from scavengers.

animals.name: Jaguar
animals.description: The largest cat in the Americas, known for its powerful build and distinctive rosette patterns with central spots.
facts: Has strongest bite of all big cats
Loves water and excellent swimmer
Can crush turtle shells with jaws
Rosettes help camouflage in dappled light
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by deforestation and conflict with ranchers.
animals.dietInfo: Eats over 85 species including capybara, peccary, and caiman.
animals.behavior: Solitary and crepuscular. Uses powerful bite to pierce skulls of prey.

animals.name: Gorilla
animals.description: The largest living primates, sharing 98% of DNA with humans and living in complex social groups.
facts: Can use simple tools in wild
Build new nests every night
Silverbacks lead family groups
Communicate with 25 different sounds
animals.conservationInfo: Critically endangered due to habitat loss, poaching, and disease.
animals.dietInfo: Eats stems, bamboo shoots, and fruits. Spend 30% of day feeding.
animals.behavior: Live in stable family groups led by dominant silverback males.

animals.name: Chimpanzee
animals.description: Our closest living relatives, sharing 98.7% of DNA with humans and displaying complex social behaviors.
facts: Use more tools than any animal except humans
Can learn sign language
Hunt in coordinated groups
Have unique cultures across different groups
animals.conservationInfo: Endangered due to habitat loss, poaching, and disease.
animals.dietInfo: Eats fruits, leaves, insects, and occasionally hunt small mammals.
animals.behavior: Live in complex social communities with distinct hierarchies.

animals.name: Orangutan
animals.description: The 'person of the forest' is one of our closest relatives and the largest arboreal mammal.
facts: Build new nests every night in trees
Use leaves as umbrellas and tools
Males develop large cheek pads when mature
Can live up to 50 years in wild
animals.conservationInfo: Critically endangered due to deforestation for palm oil plantations.
animals.dietInfo: Eat over 400 types of food including fruits, leaves, bark, and insects.
animals.behavior: Mostly solitary. Females raise offspring for 6-8 years.

animals.name: Bonobo
animals.description: Closely related to chimpanzees but with a more slender build and peaceful, matriarchal society.
facts: Resolve conflicts through sexual behavior
Walk upright more easily than chimps
Have more human-like facial expressions
Live in matriarchal societies
animals.conservationInfo: Endangered due to habitat loss and hunting.
animals.dietInfo: Eats fruits, leaves, flowers, and occasionally small animals.
animals.behavior: Peaceful and use sexual behavior for social bonding and conflict resolution.

animals.name: Gibbon
animals.description: The smallest and most acrobatic apes, known for their incredible brachiation through forest canopies.
facts: Can swing at 55 km/h through trees
Sing complex duets with mates
Have the longest arms relative to body
Monogamous and form strong pair bonds
animals.conservationInfo: Endangered due to habitat loss and illegal pet trade.
animals.dietInfo: Eats fruits, leaves, flowers, and occasionally insects and eggs.
animals.behavior: Highly territorial and use loud calls to defend their territory.

animals.name: Rhinoceros
animals.description: Massive herbivores known for their distinctive horns and thick protective skin.
facts: Horns made of keratin, like human hair
Can run up to 50 km/h
Have poor eyesight but excellent hearing
Wallow in mud to protect from sun and insects
animals.conservationInfo: Critically endangered due to poaching for their horns.
animals.dietInfo: Graze on grasses, leaves, shoots, and branches.
animals.behavior: Mostly solitary except for mothers with calves. Can be aggressive when threatened.

animals.name: Zebra
animals.description: Known for their distinctive black and white stripes, each zebra has a unique pattern like human fingerprints.
facts: Stripes may confuse predators and insects
Can run up to 65 km/h
Sleep standing up in groups for protection
Stripes are vertical on body, horizontal on legs
animals.conservationInfo: Some species threatened by habitat loss and hunting.
animals.dietInfo: Graze on grasses and occasionally leaves and buds.
animals.behavior: Social animals that live in herds. Migrate long distances for food and water.

animals.name: Moose
animals.description: The largest member of the deer family, known for their massive size, broad antlers, and distinctive drooping snout.
facts: Antlers can span 2 meters across
Excellent swimmers can dive 5 meters deep
Can run 35 km/h despite large size
Eat up to 25 kg of vegetation daily
animals.conservationInfo: Stable populations but threatened by habitat loss in some areas.
animals.dietInfo: Eats aquatic plants, leaves, twigs, and bark.
animals.behavior: Mostly solitary except during mating season. Excellent swimmers.

animals.name: Bison
animals.description: The largest land animal in North America, once numbering in the millions before near extinction.
facts: Can run up to 55 km/h
Hump made of muscle for plowing snow
Nearly went extinct in 19th century
National mammal of the United States
animals.conservationInfo: Recovering through conservation efforts after near extinction.
animals.dietInfo: Graze on grasses, herbs, and shrubs.
animals.behavior: Social animals that live in herds. Migrate seasonally for food.

animals.name: Ostrich
animals.description: The world's largest bird, known for its long neck, powerful legs, and inability to fly.
facts: Largest bird eggs in the world
Can run 70 km/h for 30 minutes
Eyes are larger than their brain
Only bird with two toes on each foot
animals.conservationInfo: Widespread and common, though some subspecies threatened.
animals.dietInfo: Eats plants, roots, seeds, insects, and small reptiles.
animals.behavior: Live in flocks. Use powerful kicks for defense against predators.

animals.name: Flamingo
animals.description: Known for their vibrant pink feathers, long legs, and distinctive curved bills used for filter feeding.
facts: Get pink color from beta-carotene in diet
Can stand on one leg for hours
Eat with head upside down
Live in colonies of thousands
animals.conservationInfo: Some species threatened by habitat loss and pollution.
animals.dietInfo: Filter feed on algae, crustaceans, and small fish.
animals.behavior: Highly social birds that perform synchronized group displays.

animals.name: Peacock
animals.description: Known for the male's spectacular tail feathers with eye-like patterns, which they display during courtship.
facts: Only males are called peacocks
Tail feathers can be 60% of body length
Can fly despite large tail
Loud calls can be heard far distances
animals.conservationInfo: Common in wild and widely kept in captivity.
animals.dietInfo: Eats plants, flower petals, seeds, insects, and small reptiles.
animals.behavior: Males display elaborate courtship dances to attract females.

animals.name: Octopus
animals.description: Highly intelligent invertebrates known for their eight arms, camouflage abilities, and problem-solving skills.
facts: Three hearts and blue blood
Can change color and texture instantly
Use tools and solve complex puzzles
Release ink cloud to escape predators
animals.conservationInfo: Most species not threatened, but sensitive to ocean pollution.
animals.dietInfo: Eats crabs, shrimp, fish, and other shellfish.
animals.behavior: Solitary and intelligent. Excellent at camouflage and escape.

animals.name: Sea Turtle
animals.description: Ancient mariners that have existed since the time of dinosaurs, known for their long migrations.
facts: Can migrate thousands of kilometers
Return to birthplace to nest
Can hold breath for 5 hours when resting
Temperature determines hatchling gender
animals.conservationInfo: All species threatened by plastic pollution, fishing nets, and habitat loss.
animals.dietInfo: Varies by species from jellyfish to seagrass to sponges.
animals.behavior: Migrate long distances. Females return to natal beaches to lay eggs.

animals.name: Pufferfish
animals.description: Known for their ability to inflate their bodies with water or air when threatened, and for containing deadly toxins.
facts: One of most poisonous vertebrates
Tetrodotoxin is 1,200 times deadlier than cyanide
Some species create sand circles for nests
Teeth fused into beak-like structure
animals.conservationInfo: Most species not threatened, but some affected by habitat loss.
animals.dietInfo: Eats algae, corals, sponges, and small invertebrates.
animals.behavior: Slow swimmers that rely on inflation and toxins for defense.

animals.name: Seahorse
animals.description: Unique fish with horse-like heads, prehensile tails, and the unusual trait of males giving birth.
facts: Males get pregnant and give birth
Eyes move independently
Can change color for camouflage
Monogamous and mate for life
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by habitat loss and traditional medicine trade.
animals.dietInfo: Eat small crustaceans by sucking them through their snouts.
animals.behavior: Poor swimmers that anchor themselves with tails. Form monogamous pairs.

animals.name: Sloth
animals.description: Known for their extremely slow movement, spending most of their lives hanging upside down in trees.
facts: Only come down from trees once a week
Move so slowly algae grows on their fur
Can rotate head 270 degrees
Metabolism is slowest of any mammal
animals.conservationInfo: Some species threatened by habitat loss.
animals.dietInfo: Eat leaves, twigs, and fruits. Have multi-chambered stomachs for digestion.
animals.behavior: Solitary and nocturnal. Spend 15-20 hours sleeping daily.

animals.name: Armadillo
animals.description: Unique mammals known for their protective bony plates and ability to roll into a ball for defense.
facts: Only mammal with protective shell
Can hold breath for 6 minutes underwater
Always give birth to identical quadruplets
Sleep 16-18 hours per day
animals.conservationInfo: Most species not threatened, but some endangered.
animals.dietInfo: Eat insects, grubs, plants, and small vertebrates.
animals.behavior: Mostly nocturnal. Excellent diggers that live in burrows.

animals.name: Meerkat
animals.description: Small social mongoose known for standing upright on hind legs and living in cooperative groups.
facts: Live in groups called mobs or gangs
Have dark eye patches to reduce sun glare
Immune to scorpion venom
Take turns as lookouts for predators
animals.conservationInfo: Widespread and common in protected areas.
animals.dietInfo: Eat insects, spiders, scorpions, small reptiles, and eggs.
animals.behavior: Highly social with complex group dynamics and cooperative breeding.

animals.name: Wolverine
animals.description: The largest land-dwelling member of the weasel family, known for their strength and ferocity despite small size.
facts: Can take down prey 5 times their size
Have special molars for crushing frozen meat
Travel 15-20 km daily for food
Strong smell used to mark territory
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by habitat fragmentation and climate change.
animals.dietInfo: Eat carrion, small mammals, and occasionally larger prey.
animals.behavior: Solitary and territorial. Excellent climbers and swimmers.

animals.name: Manta Ray
animals.description: Graceful giants of the ocean known for their wing-like pectoral fins and intelligence.
facts: Largest brain-to-body ratio of any fish
Can recognize themselves in mirrors
Perform acrobatic leaps from water
Visit cleaning stations for parasite removal
animals.conservationInfo: Threatened by fishing, bycatch, and habitat degradation.
animals.dietInfo: Filter feed on plankton, small fish, and crustaceans.
animals.behavior: Generally solitary but gather in large groups for feeding and mating.

animals.name: Axolotl
animals.description: Unique salamanders that remain in their larval form throughout life, known for their remarkable regeneration abilities.
facts: Can regenerate limbs, spine, and even brain
Never undergo metamorphosis
Have feathery external gills
Come in various color morphs
animals.conservationInfo: Critically endangered in wild due to habitat loss and pollution.
animals.dietInfo: Eat worms, insects, small fish, and crustaceans.
animals.behavior: Mostly inactive, spending time at bottom of lakes. Nocturnal hunters.

animals.name: Tasmanian Tiger
animals.description: Also known as the thylacine, this marsupial carnivore had tiger-like stripes on its lower back and a wolf-like appearance. It was the largest known carnivorous marsupial of modern times.
facts: Was a marsupial, not a true tiger
Could open its jaw 120 degrees
Had a pouch that opened backward
Last known individual died in 1936
animals.conservationInfo: Went extinct due to hunting, habitat loss, and disease. The last known thylacine died in Hobart Zoo in 1936.
animals.dietInfo: Hunted small mammals and birds. Was often blamed for killing sheep, leading to bounty hunting.
animals.behavior: Mostly nocturnal and shy. Could hop on hind legs like a kangaroo.

animals.name: Woolly Mammoth
animals.description: An enormous elephant-like creature adapted to the ice age with long curved tusks and a thick coat of fur. They coexisted with early humans.
facts: Tusks could grow up to 5 meters long
Had a hump of fat for energy storage
Lived during the last Ice Age
Well-preserved specimens found in permafrost
animals.conservationInfo: Went extinct about 4,000 years ago due to climate change and human hunting. Scientists are working on de-extinction projects.
animals.dietInfo: Graised on grasses, shrubs, and other tundra vegetation. Used tusks to clear snow.
animals.behavior: Lived in matriarchal herds similar to modern elephants. Migrated seasonally.

animals.name: Dodo
animals.description: A flightless bird that became the symbol of extinction. It had a large hooked beak, stubby wings, and was completely unafraid of humans.
facts: Could not fly due to island evolution
Had no natural predators until humans arrived
Became extinct less than 100 years after discovery
Related to pigeons and doves
animals.conservationInfo: Went extinct in the late 17th century due to hunting by sailors and predation by introduced animals like rats, pigs, and monkeys.
animals.dietInfo: Ate fruits, nuts, seeds, and roots. Possibly used stones to help digest food.
animals.behavior: Was fearless of humans due to island isolation. Nested on the ground.

animals.name: Saber-toothed Cat
animals.description: One of the most famous prehistoric predators, known for its enormous curved canine teeth that could grow up to 28 cm long.
facts: Canine teeth were serrated like steak knives
Could open jaw 120 degrees for biting
Was more muscular than modern big cats
Hunted large prehistoric mammals
animals.conservationInfo: Went extinct about 10,000 years ago during the Quaternary extinction event, likely due to climate change and human impact.
animals.dietInfo: Hunted large herbivores like bison, camels, and ground sloths. Used ambush tactics.
animals.behavior: Likely social animals that lived in groups. Used powerful forelimbs to hold prey.

animals.name: Irish Elk
animals.description: The largest deer that ever lived, famous for its enormous antlers that could span up to 3.65 meters from tip to tip.
facts: Antlers were the largest of any known deer
Weighed about 40 kg - as much as a child
Despite the name, was more closely related to fallow deer
Antlers were shed and regrown annually
animals.conservationInfo: Went extinct about 7,700 years ago. The massive antlers may have contributed to its extinction during environmental changes.
animals.dietInfo: Browsed on grasses, leaves, and shrubs in open woodlands and grasslands.
animals.behavior: Likely lived in herds. Males used antlers for display and combat during mating season.

animals.name: Great Auk
animals.description: A flightless seabird that was the original 'penguin.' It was a powerful swimmer but clumsy on land, making it vulnerable to hunters.
facts: Was the original bird called 'penguin'
Could dive to depths of 75 meters
Spent most of its life at sea
Nested in dense colonies on remote islands
animals.conservationInfo: Hunted to extinction for its feathers, meat, and oil. The last pair was killed in 1844 on Eldey Island, Iceland.
animals.dietInfo: Ate fish including menhaden and capelin, along with crustaceans.
animals.behavior: Excellent swimmer but vulnerable on land. Nested in large, dense colonies.

animals.name: Quagga
animals.description: A unique subspecies of plains zebra with stripes only on the front part of its body. The rear was brown like a horse.
facts: Stripes faded toward the rear of the body
Was the first extinct animal to have its DNA studied
Name comes from its distinctive call 'kwa-ha-ha'
There are projects to breed back quagga-like zebras
animals.conservationInfo: Hunted to extinction in the wild by the 1870s for its meat and hide. The last captive quagga died in 1883 in Amsterdam.
animals.dietInfo: Grazed on grasses in the South African grasslands and savannas.
animals.behavior: Lived in herds like other zebras. Was known for its distinctive braying call.

animals.name: Carolina Parakeet
animals.description: The only parrot species native to the eastern United States. It had bright green plumage with a yellow head and orange face.
facts: Was the only parrot native to eastern North America
Fed on cockleburs and other weed seeds
Flocked to injured members, making them easy to hunt
Last wild sighting was in 1904
animals.conservationInfo: Went extinct due to habitat destruction, hunting for feathers, and persecution as crop pests. The last individual died in captivity in 1918.
animals.dietInfo: Ate seeds of various plants including cockleburs, thistles, and sometimes fruit and crops.
animals.behavior: Highly social birds that lived in large, noisy flocks. Would flock to injured companions.

animals.name: Steller's Sea Cow
animals.description: A gigantic relative of the manatee and dugong that was the largest sirenian ever known. It was discovered in 1741 and extinct by 1768.
facts: Was the largest sirenian ever recorded
Weighed up to 10 tons - as much as some whales
Had bark-like skin up to 3 cm thick
Was completely tame and unafraid of humans
animals.conservationInfo: Hunted to extinction within 27 years of its discovery by European explorers. Its slow reproduction rate couldn't sustain the hunting pressure.
animals.dietInfo: Grazed on kelp and other marine vegetation in shallow coastal waters.
animals.behavior: Lived in small family groups. Was slow-moving and completely unafraid of humans.

animals.name: Passenger Pigeon
animals.description: Once the most abundant bird in North America, with flocks so large they could darken the sky for days. The species went from billions to zero in about 50 years.
facts: Flocks contained billions of birds
Could fly at 100 km/h
Nesting colonies could cover hundreds of square miles
Last individual 'Martha' died in 1914
animals.conservationInfo: Hunted to extinction through commercial hunting and habitat loss. The last passenger pigeon, Martha, died at Cincinnati Zoo in 1914.
animals.dietInfo: Ate mast (nuts like acorns and chestnuts), berries, and insects.
animals.behavior: Migrated in enormous flocks. Nested in massive colonies that broke tree branches with their weight.
